Prove if the following formula is a tautology using natural deduction:

[(p → q) ∧ (q → r)] → (p → r)
message_2:
To prove that the formula [(p → q) ∧ (q → r)] → (p → r) is a tautology using natural deduction, we will use the following rules of inference: Modus Ponens (MP), Conjunction Introduction (∧I), and Implication Introduction (→I). 

We will assume the antecedent [(p → q) ∧ (q → r)] and show that the consequent (p → r) follows from it. Here's the proof:

1. (p → q) ∧ (q → r) (Assumption)
2. p → q (1, ∧-Elimination)
3. q → r (1, ∧-Elimination)
4. Assume p (Assumption)
5. q (2, 4, Modus Ponens)
6. r (3, 5, Modus Ponens)
7. p → r (4-6, Implication Introduction)
8. [(p → q) ∧ (q → r)] → (p → r) (1-7, Implication Introduction)

Thus, the formula [(p → q) ∧ (q → r)] → (p → r) is a tautology, as we have shown that assuming the antecedent leads to the consequent using natural deduction rules.
